prompt: Analyze the Big Five personality traits (OCEAN) and evaluate their predictive validity for life outcomes such as academic success, job performance, health, and relationships.

criteria.name: Conceptual Mastery of Big Five
criteria.description: Accurate explanation of Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Thoroughly defines each trait, typical behaviors, and measurement approaches (e.g., NEO-PI-R), noting trait stability and heritability.
performance_descriptors.good: Accurately defines the five traits with minor omissions or limited methodological detail.
performance_descriptors.average: Basic definitions with occasional inaccuracies or oversimplifications.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Partial or unclear explanation with notable inaccuracies.
performance_descriptors.poor: Fails to correctly describe core traits.

criteria.name: Predictive Validity Analysis
criteria.description: Evaluates how traits predict outcomes across domains.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Makes precise, evidence-informed claims linking traits to outcomes (e.g., Conscientiousness and job/academic performance; Neuroticism and mental health), noting effect sizes and boundary conditions.
performance_descriptors.good: Explains several trait-outcome links with reasonable accuracy and some nuance.
performance_descriptors.average: Lists general associations without depth or qualifiers.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Sparse or unsupported associations; limited understanding of predictive scope.
performance_descriptors.poor: No meaningful analysis of predictive validity.

criteria.name: Methodological and Cultural Considerations
criteria.description: Addresses measurement, cross-cultural generalizability, and limitations.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Critically considers measurement instruments, self-report bias, cross-cultural replication, and incremental validity over other models.
performance_descriptors.good: Mentions at least two methodological or cultural issues with some analysis.
performance_descriptors.average: Acknowledges issues superficially with limited evaluation.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Minimal methodological reflection; lacks cultural perspective.
performance_descriptors.poor: No attention to methods or cultural context.

criteria.name: Use of Evidence and Examples
criteria.description: Integrates studies, meta-analytic findings, or realistic examples.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Uses specific, relevant evidence or illustrative examples to support claims and contrasts conflicting findings.
performance_descriptors.good: Includes relevant examples or general evidence with minor gaps.
performance_descriptors.average: Examples are generic or weakly connected to claims.

criteria.name: Organization and Clarity
criteria.description: Logical structure, coherent flow, clear writing.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Clear thesis, logical progression, smooth transitions, precise language.
performance_descriptors.good: Mostly clear structure with minor redundancies.

key_points: Define each trait and typical behavioral indicators; note common instruments (e.g., NEO-PI-R, BFI).
Explain strongest predictive links: Conscientiousness with performance and health behaviors; Neuroticism with anxiety/depression and relationship strain.
Discuss incremental validity over IQ for academic/work outcomes and interactions among traits.
Address self-report bias, informant reports, and cross-cultural structure replicability.
Include practical implications for selection, coaching, and well-being interventions.
llm_questions: Summarize the Big Five traits with behavioral examples.
What evidence links Conscientiousness to academic and job performance?
How does Neuroticism relate to mental and physical health outcomes?
Explain incremental validity of personality over cognitive ability.
What are limitations of self-report personality measures and how can they be mitigated?
